author: chunwei
pre_context: Considering uncertainties in data, models allow for each time point to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and variance given by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may be influenced by the mean. While the lack of data is a serious concern for modellers, a key issue in understanding model predictions is how the available data (confirmed cases) aligns with such predictions. Confirmed cases consist of individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, were tested, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed. In contrast, the infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms or testing outcomes. Confirmed cases represent only a portion of the total infected population predicted by models, with the hidden epidemic likened to the submerged part of an iceberg, highlighting the fraction of infected individuals unknown to public health surveillance and testing. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate (b) by fitting it to confirmed cases data, it is essential to adjust for the total number of infectious individuals (IðtÞ) using the case-infection ratio (r) to accurately predict confirmed cases. By varying the ratio r, different values for b can be determined by fitting the model to data, influencing the basic reproduction number (R0) and the scale of the epidemic. The wide range of potential case-infection ratios for COVID-19 leads to a broad range of estimated transmission rates and therefore diverse model predictions. This nonidentifiability, where various combinations of parameters can fit the data well but produce different predictions, impacts the reliability of model outcomes. The standard nonlinear least squares method may not effectively address nonidentifiability as it uses a simple optimization algorithm that may not find the best solution. Different parameter choices with similar data fits can yield vastly different model predictions. The approach to managing nonidentifiability in model calibration significantly affects the accuracy of model forecasts.

author: enrique
pre_context: Utilizing technical, surveillance, and administrative data, along with published literature, can be challenging for model calibration, especially during outbreaks of unknown pathogens like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. One approach to address this challenge is through improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce confidence or credible intervals. We successfully achieved this objective using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm in our fitting procedure. The baseline predictions for Hubei, based on randomly sampling the posterior distribution, are shown in Table 1, with parameter values and credible intervals. Our Bayesian inference used newly confirmed cases in Hubei from official reports between January 21 and February 4, 2020, during the lockdown period before further control measures were implemented. The projections represent estimates for the hypothetical epidemic in Hubei if additional control measures were not put in place after February 7. Figures 4(a) and (b) depict the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 25, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 20 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimates, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases would be around 120,000, and the epidemic in Hubei would not be contained until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying recovery times for different severity levels of the virus, with durations generally increasing with acuity. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or die, with the probability of death rising with age. When a susceptible individual interacts with an infected person, the virus may be transmitted with a probability of β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4–6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2–2.7. The choice of β = 0.016 in Covasim was based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values, with weightings of 10:2:2:1, were selected to align with time-use surveys and studies of infections with known contact types, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. When considering default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, without interventions, around 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, like physical distancing, can modify the value of β. Individual variation in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness is accounted for by modeling differences in viral load. We assume two stages of viral load: an early high stage lasting 30% of infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter, followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45, aligning with international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. Daily viral load adjusts the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent each day. Fig 2 illustrates viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameters. Transmission proportions are influenced by these factors.

pre_context: Covasim is a model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. In the model, recovery times differ for asymptomatic patients, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms. Critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability of transmission denoted by β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4–6 days and an R0 of 2.2–2.7. author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the user must adjust this parameter according to local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If the network structure includes realistic settings such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary based on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values are chosen based on relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, which align with surveys and studies on known contact types. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events by contact layer is around 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can also impact the value of β. Moreover, individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each state, and infectiousness are accounted for in the model through variations in viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability per contact (β) for an individual on a specific day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location, as seen in the estimated proportions for Seattle. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced when the infectious individual is asymptomatic. We operate under the default assumption that it is not, but include a parameter that can be adjusted as necessary based on the model or context, considering that some studies use lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals.
